HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Distinguishing API calls made by long-lived token user
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an SLC Operator, I would like to know if an API call was made by the principal user or by an app 
using long-lived token on behalf of the user, so that if issues arise I can narrow down the potential source.

A session is considered a long lived session if Expiration-createDate > 8hrs
<Janko> Danil, yuo need this now? hardLogout - createTime > $config.hardLogout
Comparison is done in minutes to avoid certain time issues

Acceptance Criteria:
Whenever a call is made to API using a long-lived session, a message is issued into the api log
Documentation about the parameter on confluence
Defect for Storm and Dark Knights for adding this info into the runbooks and/or Storm documentation 

Demo Script:
A Lucky Striker will make few api calls using long-lived session tokens. He will then open the API logs and show the logs made by the app. He will point to the parameter.

Message:
Using long-lived session <sessionId> belonging to app <appName>
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Distinguishing API calls made by long-lived token user
HierarchicalRequirement.ReleaseNoteDescription:
If an API call is made by an application using long-lived session token, a message is now emitted to the logs:

Using long-lived session <token> belonging to app <client_id>

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) IMPLEMENT API PROOF OF CONCEPT (Objective)

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) PROOF OF CONCEPT (Objective)
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Using a variety of techniques to determine the best way(s) to improve API performance. This is a "Proof of Concept" at this time. The result will be set of improvements with the explanations of their intended implementations.


WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

The API is still too slow. LOS loads are currently several hundred percent higher than recommended SLAs. Many factors, including interaction with security, the data store, and the network affect performance. So we need to assess a large number of options quickly before deciding on the optimal combination of improvements to implement.


HOW WILL WE KNOW THIS WORKS?

We will have a proven strategy for making changes that will API performance.


HAPPY PATH TESTING

We will get baseline benchmark performance data for a variety of use cases. At least some of this work will come from the logging work currently in progress in Pantheon.


SAD PATH TESTING

We will use a variety of data sets to create scenarios or use cases that help us assess the effect of potential improvements.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) PROOF OF CONCEPT (Objective)

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) Approve and Refine Selectors
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
from Ilya, 9/10/2012: "PO organization is OK to go ahead with selectors. However, we still need to engage A&M and make sure that Paul's concerns re: selectors have been addressed. We are in the process of scheduling a call with him this week."

dlw: marking complete, pending A&M response




TO DO:

  • Create performance comparison based on use case: Get all data for a student.
  • Close open questions.
  • Get approval.

OPEN ISSUES RE: SELECTORS

  • Until approved for public release, selector functionality should be turned off.
  • Will Selectors be released to the public? (See Ilya's notes below)
  • What additional constraints, if any, will we apply?
  • What small modifications to the grammar do we need to make?
  • How do we formally describe the grammar in a normative specification?
-----------------------------------------------------------

FROM ILYA, 3PM, SEP 4:

Before we can move forward with Selectors:
  1. MM: Need to understand performance implications (selectors may end up too popular, so people use nothing but - need to know what that would mean in terms of system performance)
  2. PT: Need normative documentation down to field and entity names - need to check with Paul what he had in mind there
  3. PT: Entities names (e.g. studentSchoolAssociation) should not be shortened in the grammar
  4. MM: Selectors need more socialization so we can eliminate remaining open questions
-----------------------------------------------------------
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) Approve and Refine Selectors

Limit the querying capability of the current API. Restricting queries to those with existing indices


ACCEPTANCE:
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) Constrain Queries

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) Cross-Request Scope Cached Security Tokens
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Extending the scope of cached tokens to:
  • Live beyond a single request.
  • Higher-level nodes on the trace.
  • Determine criteria for flushing the cache:
    • Bind cached by instance count limit
    • Bind cache by size (LRU)
    • Bind cache by time (stamp)
    • Invalidate cache for user context on PUT, POST, DELETE

WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

Further eliminate security context traversals.

HOW WILL WE KNOW THIS WORKS?

Subsequent identical requests will be faster than original request.

HAPPY PATH TESTING

Use CI monitoring tools and new tests for multiple requests.

SAD PATH TESTING
  • Use CI monitoring tools
  • Check for cache to big
  • Check for cache invalid
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) Cross-Request Scope Cached Security Tokens

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) Persisted Security Tokens
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Persisting the cache of security tokens to avoid the constraint of bounded memory and system failure.

Same as 2546 (Cross-scope-request cache) but persisted to datastore.
  • Standing up secondary data store
  • Runbook changes

WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

It will be faster to retrieve cached values than it is to recalculate them.

HOW WILL WE KNOW THIS WORKS?

New requests will retain the performance of previously cross-request-cached requests. 

HAPPY PATH TESTING

Use CI monitoring.

SAD PATH TESTING

N/A
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) Persisted Security Tokens

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) Implement Improved Network Payload Granularity
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
This is the implementation portion of the story.
  • Take capability that we have for LOS and make it horizontal; works for any entity in the system.
  • Has to be documented.
  • Client-specified override whereby they get more or less than default return.


WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Server functionality: Return a payload that is different (probably larger) than the default entity and be able to document it.

Client functionality: Allow users to specify what they want returned in a parameterized fashion.

This functionality should be horizontal across the entire system.


WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

Improves network performance on band-width-constrained devices and reduces chattiness of API.


HOW WILL WE KNOW THIS WORKS?

Server Side: Payload centered on an entity that returns a tree of arbitrary depth.
Client Side: Ability for user to specify a different depth (greater or lesser) economically.


HAPPY PATH TESTING

TBD

SAD PATH TESTING

TBD
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) Implement Improved Network Payload Granularity

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) SPIKE: Specification for Improved Network Payload Granularity
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
This is the specification portion of the story.

"Meta-customizable view paradigm."
"Cost model?"

Replaces our "views" approach that was a one-off for Dashboard.

OUTPUT: A document describing the best implementation.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
1) A document/wiki page describing the specification (on or near API design guidelines).
2) A syntax for specifying the tree to return as URI parameter.
3) An XML schema for specifying the default tree.
4) Examples of the URI and XML syntax and what gets returned.
5) A means of specifying wildcards.
6) A means of specifying exclusion by exception (contrary to wildcard).

https://thesli.onconfluence.com/display/sli/Specification+for+Improved+Network+Payload+Granularity

The following are stretch that could clarify the design (they are credits for the implementation story).

7) An immutable Java model of the Selector and Feature (Stretch).
8) A StAX-based parser for the XML representation (Stretch).
9) A Pull Parser for the URI representation (Stretch).
10) A validator that checks the Java Model against the logical model (stretch).
10) A StAX-based writer for the XML representation (Stretch).
11) A serializer for the URI version (Stretch). 
12) Tests for the code parts.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Server functionality: Return a payload that is different (probably larger) than the default entity and be able to document it.

Client functionality: Allow users to specify what they want returned in a parameterized fashion.

This functionality should be horizontal across the entire system.


WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

Improves network performance on band-width-constrained devices and reduces chattiness of API.


HOW WILL WE KNOW THIS WORKS?

Server Side: Payload centered on an entity that returns a tree of arbitrary depth.
Client Side: Ability for user to specify a different depth (greater or lesser) economically.


HAPPY PATH TESTING

TBD

SAD PATH TESTING

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Performance) Use CI to Provide Information on Changes in Performance
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Measuring API performance on an on-going basis and automatically detecting degradation. (Regression testing.)

Performance monitoring in CI:
  • Use "off the shelf" framework; don't over-invest! (Don't build the Taj Mahal!)
  • Set up single Jenkins job.
  • Run. Analyze. 
  • Start with LOS.
  • Define notification system.
Get:
  • Round-trip time for any call (also see Pantheon).
  • Trend analysis for each call (historical data).
  • Set build to "Yellow" on degradation of performance.
  • Set to run at certain time of day (to account for AWS afternoon slow-down).

"We just want to know when an API call starts to suck."



WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

To determine effectiveness of POC efforts to meet SLAs.  To immediately identify a code change that has a significant negative impact on performance.


HOW WILL WE KNOW THIS WORKS?

Parse a log file and generate a repeatable report that shows performance changes with specific alerts for degradation with each CI build.


HAPPY PATH TESTING

N/A

SAD PATH TESTING

N/A
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Performance) Use CI to Provide Information on Changes in Performance

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Hygiene) PATCH
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
comments from US1686:
Sean: There's an epic here with some spiking we should do to figure out how we want to handle this.  There a two primary applications of PATCH:
1. An app only wants to update only part of the resource to reduce traffic
2. An app is updating part of a resource that represents the total resource that a user is able to access.  For example, if a PUT occurs that includes fields that the user cannot modify, the API will either consider these as unauthorized (if the PUT includes the restricted field) or a complete representation if the restricted field is not included.

#2 is the more important aspect that we haven't solved; #1 is nice to have.

<James Short, 7/9/12>  I have implemented PATCH and have it commented out in DefaultCrudResource and it handles #1.  And I'm 80% sure it handles #2.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Hygiene) PATCH

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: API: (Hygiene) White List Validation Framework + Implementation
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Whitelist input validation should be defined and implemented for a "core" set of entities (the entities that are most heavily used like teacher, staff, student, etc.) for the Alpha.1 release. 
  • Create Framework/Rules Library
  • Implement for core entities:
    • Student
    • Staff
    • EdOrg
(Add new entities incrementally each sprint through v1)


WHY ARE WE DOING IT?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Requested by Dan Fiedler:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The security office would like to have whitelist input validation performed on all data handled by SLI (either through ingestion or the API.)  In the past, a simple character blacklist was implemented at the data access layer to prevent SLI from persisting data that contained potentially dangerous characters.  Later this mechanism was also used to prevent handling of API requests that contained potentially dangerous characters in URL/querystring parameters.  

For each entity in SLI, an input validation mechanism should verify that the input matches a tightly defined specification (whitelist) of valid input and reject all input that does not match this specification.  For example, whitelist validation via regex or data format may enforce a certain format as well as limiting the characters allowed (e.g. a US zip code is 5 digits plus an optional dash and four more digits; an email address has a certain format that can be validated used a regex.  A person's name may reasonably contain only alphanumeric characters and limited punctuation such as apostrophes.)

The blacklist input validation security control can remain in place and be used in combination with whitelist input validation.

An iterative approach to implementing the whitelist input validation security control is acceptable.  Whitelist input validation should be defined and implemented for a "core" set of entities (the entities that are most heavily used like teacher, staff, student, etc.) for the Alpha.1 release.   Whitelist input validation can be defined and implemented for other entity types for future releases; adding a set of the next most important entities with each release.  

The team can determine what exactly the "core" set of entities consists of.  The team should work with the security office in the design and review of the control


------------------

INFOSEC MEETING: 7/16

Ilya: what is the security benefit?

Dan: security case for input validation. It should only handle requests for data is well-formed and meets specifications. This is to protect against injection attacks.

Ilya: 

Dan: in general, the blacklist input validation won't protect against  against injection-style in the context of Javascript, HTML attribute, CSS context... If you take the system as a whole, you can 

We can back off on restrictions where it makes sense.

Don't want to get bogged down on a specific field.

Dan: zip code = If you were accepting many characters and some Javascript gets in

Dan: There are still ways to encode things with with Javascript

Dan: If we are thorough about things like single quotes and double-quotes in a field, or any delimiter, we can prevent attacks.

Ilya: This could be a very expensive story. It looks really big and we don't know where it stops.

The goal is to find a general pattern that can be applied.

We have our data model and ask what kind of data we need to accept.

Is a whitelist approach common in web applications?

Don't we have to have a structure for what is coming in.

Can Dan help us? YES!!!

Can districts tenant turns this on and off? 

Ilya: I would like it to make it a goal of having the smallest set of limits possible on the largest number of fields possible.

Boaz: I think categories of fields need to be 

Dan: As long as you can trace back the data and none of that was applied by a user...

-------------------------------

Set up a meeting with Dan, Ilya, and team to talk about a generalized approach. I will put a spike in 5.2 to account for this.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: API: (Hygiene) White List Validation Framework + Implementation

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: HATEOAS Links Returned as Map
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
From: Anthony Arroyo via Dev Mailing List
Story added to backlog per Matt à Ilya à Steve

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
This is more of a feature suggestion than anything else, so take it for what it's worth.
 
Is there a particular reason why the "links" section of the JSON response is a list and not a dict (I'm using Python terminology here)? It seems like the HATEOAS-ness of the API would be much better if I could (in python) just call results['links']['getStudents'], instead of having to navigate to the links list and then iterate through the list in order to find the desired link. With results of any size, this soon becomes very laggy.
 
If I had the links returned as a dict with the "rel" as a key and the "href" as a value, I'd be able to truly make an HATEOAS application. Unless I'm missing something. Food for thought.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: HATEOAS Links Returned as Map

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: SPIKE: White List Validation Framework + Implementation
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Agreed as of InfoSec meeting of 7/16:
  • Set up meeting with Ilya, Dan, and Team
  • Have Dan develop a generalized approach
  • Discuss implications for ingestion
  • Discuss implications for...?
  • Estimate cost
  • Deliver options to management



-------------------------------
WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Whitelist input validation should be defined and implemented for a "core" set of entities (the entities that are most heavily used like teacher, staff, student, etc.) for the Alpha.1 release. 
  • Create Framework/Rules Library
  • Implement for core entities:
    • Student
    • Staff
    • EdOrg
(Add new entities incrementally each sprint through v1)


WHY ARE WE DOING IT?

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Requested by Dan Fiedler:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The security office would like to have whitelist input validation performed on all data handled by SLI (either through ingestion or the API.)  In the past, a simple character blacklist was implemented at the data access layer to prevent SLI from persisting data that contained potentially dangerous characters.  Later this mechanism was also used to prevent handling of API requests that contained potentially dangerous characters in URL/querystring parameters.  

For each entity in SLI, an input validation mechanism should verify that the input matches a tightly defined specification (whitelist) of valid input and reject all input that does not match this specification.  For example, whitelist validation via regex or data format may enforce a certain format as well as limiting the characters allowed (e.g. a US zip code is 5 digits plus an optional dash and four more digits; an email address has a certain format that can be validated used a regex.  A person's name may reasonably contain only alphanumeric characters and limited punctuation such as apostrophes.)

The blacklist input validation security control can remain in place and be used in combination with whitelist input validation.

An iterative approach to implementing the whitelist input validation security control is acceptable.  Whitelist input validation should be defined and implemented for a "core" set of entities (the entities that are most heavily used like teacher, staff, student, etc.) for the Alpha.1 release.   Whitelist input validation can be defined and implemented for other entity types for future releases; adding a set of the next most important entities with each release.  

The team can determine what exactly the "core" set of entities consists of.  The team should work with the security office in the design and review of the control


------------------

INFOSEC MEETING: 7/16

Ilya: what is the security benefit?

Dan: security case for input validation. It should only handle requests for data is well-formed and meets specifications. This is to protect against injection attacks.

Ilya: 

Dan: in general, the blacklist input validation won't protect against  against injection-style in the context of Javascript, HTML attribute, CSS context... If you take the system as a whole, you can 

We can back off on restrictions where it makes sense.

Don't want to get bogged down on a specific field.

Dan: zip code = If you were accepting many characters and some Javascript gets in

Dan: There are still ways to encode things with with Javascript

Dan: If we are thorough about things like single quotes and double-quotes in a field, or any delimiter, we can prevent attacks.

Ilya: This could be a very expensive story. It looks really big and we don't know where it stops.

The goal is to find a general pattern that can be applied.

We have our data model and ask what kind of data we need to accept.

Is a whitelist approach common in web applications?

Don't we have to have a structure for what is coming in.

Can Dan help us? YES!!!

Can districts tenant turns this on and off? 

Ilya: I would like it to make it a goal of having the smallest set of limits possible on the largest number of fields possible.

Boaz: I think categories of fields need to be 

Dan: As long as you can trace back the data and none of that was applied by a user...

-------------------------------

Set up a meeting with Dan, Ilya, and team to talk about a generalized approach. I will put a spike in 5.2 to account for this.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: SPIKE: White List Validation Framework + Implementation

** Only synchronize URIs **
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Synchronize API URIs with WADL

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Mongo Exception Handling
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As a user I would like to make  sure that the database exceptions are being handled.

AC:
Gracefully handle mongo exceptions when they occur
Gracefully handle means retrying a configurable number of times
If operation reached max retry count, then continue the ingestion process
It should be logged that an operation failed and a retry was necessary
Handle batch retry
Use handling conditions from confluence page (extended with retry or skip)
Unit tests added to cover new retry logic, acceptance tests not needed due to the nature of the story.
Documentation is updated

Associated Storm Defect: US1594
https://rally1.rallydev.com/#/5289701840ud/detail/defect/7634472321
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Mongo Exception Handling
HierarchicalRequirement.Notes:
Documented the scenarios that have been implemented by this story: https://thesli.onconfluence.com/display/sli/Ingestion+MongoDB+Exception+Handling (column name- 'Implemented?')



Exceptions that are thrown by Mongo and can be handled in the code:
MongoException (Network, CursorNotFound)
MongoInternalException
DataAccessResourceFailureException
InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException
InvalidDataAccessResourceUsageException

(8/24/2012)Associated Storm Defect: US1594
https://rally1.rallydev.com/#/5289701840ud/detail/defect/7634472321 -Alex

newBatchJob

Acceptance criteria:
Pits can share External cache

As a ingestion user I want to make sure my big batches do not cause OOM exception while being processed by the ingestion process

Is it high priority story? Right now we can successfully ingest a 25M data set.

POSSIBLE STORIES

Our goals include the following:
  • Improve tooling.
  • Improve generation of documentation artifacts.
  • Increased ease automated updating with CI build.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: DOCUMENTATION GENERATION AND TECH WRITER ASSISTANCE

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: DOC: Full Automation of Doc Generation Through to CI (Just CI Job)
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
NOTE: This is a carryover from 5.1. The only thing that has to happen is the get DK to get the CI stuff running. I will go to DK with request so they can make a story.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

(aka) "The Big Red Button".

  • The current system is repeatable but not fully automated.
  • Move Storm Tool Chain to Server with Oxygen so the doc can be edited and built by anyone.
  • Docs generated in CI.
  • Anyone on Storm/Wolverine can build the doc.
  • aka "The Big Red Button"

Refactor for:

  • Repeatability
  • Reliability
  • Alignment with 4 Kitchens requirements (done but needs possible future tweaking)
  • Simplicity
  • Scaleability
  • Cross-Functional Team Operation (anyone can do it)
  • Full Hand-Off to Doc Team

EVERY "CHUNK" OF DOC MUST HAVE A GUID THAT NEVER CHANGES!!!

Three must-haves:

  • Every atomic chunk of text has a unique id
  • ids don't change across doc versions
  • Existing ids do not need to be re-created manually across doc versions.  Ever.

As long as the system achieves these goals, I'm fine with it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(Steve's confirmation e-mail to 4K)

All,

Based on our phone meeting last week, I am confirming our understanding as follows:

  1. WGen will tag each "chunk" of content with a GUID. We cannot, however, guarantee that we will always and forever have only "Books, Chapters, and Sections". Nor can we know at this time whether some "chunks" might be added, merged, or removed altogether. We're also likely to need sub-sections as the product grows and the documentation becomes more detailed. As I said during our call, we are at a very early stage in the product lifecycle and can't predict how much documentation there will be a year or two from now.
  2. WGen will send 4K both HTML and XML for each documentation release.
  3. 4K will provide a “script” for WGen to use to push versions of the documentation that is ready for release to a git repository on Github. Four Kitchens will then pull the new version from the git repository and publish it.
  5. WGen will continue to follow all contractually specified obligations for delivery of material to the SLC and will prioritize those obligations over all other delivery-related considerations. Our delivery process to date has been: DocTeam --> DocPO --> WGenPM --> to SLC Basecamp account. 
  6. Under no circumstances will WGen enter content directly into the Drupal environment on the 4K site.

We look forward to talking with you further to make this process as smooth as possible for both organizations.


Steve
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: DOC: Full Automation of Doc Generation Through to CI (Just CI Job)

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Jefferson County Onboarding
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Dong and Bushra to team up and drive requirements clarification


Requirement:

As a state IT Admin I can ingest data directly through the API without a traditional ingestion process that bootstraps data.

Scenarios:

As a SEA Admin I want to create my Tenant and SEA via the API without having to go through LZ provisioning.

As a SEA Admin I want to create an IT Admin via the API so that IT Admins can create LEAs.

As a SEA Admin I want to associate IT Admins and SEA via the API so that IT Admins can create LEAs


Not in scope for R.1

District IT Admin is not needed for R1 because we are only supporting state on boarding for R1.  The ability for LEAs to create District IT Admin will be possible after R1

As a LEA Admin I want to create an ITAdmin via the API so that IT admins can ingest data via the API

As a LEA Admin I want to associate ITAdmin & LEA via the API so that IT admins can ingest data via the API


******

Current Provisioning works as implemented with this story.
Must check that after implementation, SAMT2 must work as designed.
AC:
— All we're saying is that there's a user in LDAP
— Both the ITAdmin and the Realm need to exist before the ITAdmin can log into the API.
— SEA Admin can create an ITAdmin using the SAMT tool. (maybe)
— LEA Admin can create an ITADmin using the SAMT tool (maybe)
— There needs to be a tighter control on who can create what.
--- The EdOrg, Staff and EdOrg-Staff association needs to exist. Need StaffEducationOrgAssignmentAssociation.
--- IT Admin user will call API directly, no additional admin apps are needed for the IT Admin
--- IT Admin is able to log in and make API calls
*****

See notes below as well.

Current Behavior:
In order to use the API's, a super user needs to login, provision a landing zone to have the tenancy and ed orgs added to the system.

Expected Behavior:
A state/district/developer etc. should be able to connect to the api and write all the necessary data through the API (ed orgs, enrollment,assessment etc.) to use the platform therefore requiring no ingestion to occur.

(Right now when the landing zone is provisioned it creates the EdOrg and Tenant documents therefore requiring provisioning of an LZ before you can fully use the system.)

<BI Notes from discussion with James.S>
* Today the IT Admin is a part of the staff collection that gets ingested.  Colorado wants to use the API puts/posts to make entries to mongo.  However, this will not be possible if there is no federated IT Admin in the mongo staff collection.  
* It is OK to continue with the current process of having a LZ provisioned and Ed-Org setup (even if it is not initially used). 
* The Tenant ID will come from the state's IDP

Parallax has built the SAMT that will cover the necessary UI needs:
Have a UX where an admin (available from the admin portal) can enter credentials for the federated user that will have access to the API.
StaffUniqueStateID in mongo must match the entry in state IDP and has to be entered in the UX.
After the user is created, he must have access to the API

Recommended Flow:
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Jefferson County Onboarding
HierarchicalRequirement.Notes:
6/1/2011—  COnverted to a user story from DE640

Changed priority to P2, since colorado comes on board by alpha.1

Defect specific properties:
Defect State: Rejected
Priority: Emergency Release (P2)
Severity: Causes system failure (Sev1)
Submitted By: cwilson@wgen.net
Creation Date: 2012-05-30 08:35:35 AM
Found In:
Fixed In:
Verified In:
Target Build:
Target Date:
Release Note: false
Affects Doc: false

Matt,


I have a couple comments, and then maybe the five of us should set up a time to talk early next week, since this is a "Alpha.1 vs. Alpha.X vs. R1.0" discussion.  I might even suggest Sean have a "topic of the week" forum and this be it's first focus, since this is a lot more than a defect or a story; it's an architectural issue.


>>>I could see us providing the option to bootstrap an Ed-Org during the tenant creation process…


We already do that.  By the way, we don't HAVE a tenant creation process right now, really. The entire process is just creating a user in LDAP with a "tenant=X" field where X hasn't existed before.  And when they say "edorg=Y", the first time they log in, I believe that EdOrg Y is created in mongo.  At least that's how it was explained to me that it worked/was going to work.


>>>having to support a special workflow for API-only tenants who do not want to use ingestion


Good point.  I think I am only proposing a special workflow in exactly one way:

Same for ingestion vs. API users:

Creating first superadmin

Creating first EdOrg ("top level")

Creating Realm to federate against

Different for ingestion vs. API users:

Federated user login:

- With ingestion users, this comes with the ingestion

- With API users, we need to do something where users who authenticate against the correct realm get whatever they need to function provisioned in the data store.

(However, I might argue that we should be doing this for ingestion users as well.  It would be interesting to see what comes in the Staff collection that couldn't be auto-created. Maybe Sean can stew on this).


Ilya stated that "Getting Data in through API is a complicated proces".  That is certainly true :-)


Let's talk about the two use cases for setting up a client for API-only use.  Our two customers of this feature are State/District Admins and App Developers.

- App Developers: I think most App developers would say that getting data in through the API is a far simpler thing to do than creating Ed-Fi XML.

- State/District Admins: I think that if a state has an interest in doing everything through the API, I don't think they would have any trouble creating and managing users through the API.  After all, they are signing up to manage EVERYTHING through the API.


Matt: As to your question: But do you agree with deprioritizing this out of Alpha.1?  Sounds like we'd also need to convince Pete, since he seems convinced that it's needed for JeffCo.

A: I would be fine with that depriorization, but I don’t think it does us any good.  See my comment about XML creation.


>>>What we would be asking them to do as part of onboarding is negligible in comparison.

Not really.  If we don't CRUD of staff/teachers through the API, they have to ingest them: So let's say JeffCo has 5,000 teachers/Staff who want to use the system.  Since those are Federated users, they need to be present in Mongo.  If we don't create a way to let them create/maintain teachers/staff through the API, are we going to be asking them to upload the interchange which contains Staff every night?


It is possible I am off base, and the only thing that needs to be created is the FIRST Federated IT User and that user can use the API to create the rest.  If that's the case, I would suggest we add whatever is needed to the Realm Creation dialog.


I think this requires a discussion.  However, being an architectural issue, I am going to hand it over to Mr. Melody and let him drive it as he sees fit.  I would be happy to be present at any meeting which discusses it.


Mark

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Implement 'simple'deletion POC
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an ingestion user, I would like to be able to delete Student Entity through bulk ingestion as part of a dedicated deletion job so that I can incrementally change my data rather than purging and reloading data when I want to remove entities.
 
 
What:
Deletion of a student entity  through existing ed-fi interchange within a dedicated Deletion Job
 
Investigate using existing Pipeline to process deletions versus creating a dedicated pipeline.
 
Why:
Districts will need on day N to keep their source system(s) in sync with SLI.  Also, initially, it will be one way to rectify mistakes (a tool may come later to help with this, if requested).
 
Rules:
  •  Deletions are hard deletes
  •  Respect Referential Integrity (only leaf nodes can be deleted) - SEE NOTES
  • Custom Data cannot be deleted separate from enclosing entity

 
Acceptance Criteria:
Deletion Performance SHOULD BE in the ballpark of performance for inserts. 
MUST produce User Documentation and technical documentation in Confluence
Once tradeoffs of using existing pipeline or creating separate pipeline are understood,  MUST meet with Sean and Igor to vett findings.  
Ideally, implement both deletion of student through existing and dedicated pipelines to be able to demonstrate differences. 
 
Gherkin:
Scenario: LEA Ingestion User Deleting through ingestion with single student interchange specifying deletions by full entity listing
Given I am a valid Ingestion User  (role)
And I am authenticated on SLI
And I provide a single StudentInterchange in my submission
And I provide a student entity  in the interchange which corresponds to a stored entity in SLI that has no dependencies
When I drop my submission into my landing zone, then the job completes
And the job produces a log file
And the log file contains description of what has been deleted
And, the log file contains a count of entities that have been deleted.
 
SEE NOTES
Scenario: LEA Ingestion User Deleting through ingestion with student interchange specifying deletions by full entity list with violation of referential integrity
Given I am a valid Ingestion User  (role)
And I am authenticated on SLI
And I provide a single StudentInterchange in my submission
And I provide a student entity  in the interchange which corresponds to a stored entity in SLI that has  dependencies
When I drop my submission into my landing zone, then the job completes
And the job produces an error  file
And the error file contains error stating that student entitiy with <id> could not be deleted because dependent entities exist
And the job produces a job file
And the job summary states 1 entity submitted, 0 entities deleted, 1 Error, O Warnings
 
 
Scenario: LEA Ingestion User Deleting through ingestion with student interchange specifying deletions by full entity listing referring to entity that is not in data store
Given I am a valid Ingestion User  (role)
And I am authenticated on SLI
And I provide a single StudentInterchange in my submission
And I provide a student entity  in the interchange which corresponds to an entity that doesn't exist in the SLI data store
When I drop my submission into my landing zone, then the job completes
And the job produces a job file
And the summary in the job file states that one entity was submitted and 0  entities were deleted, 0 Errors, 0 Warnings
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Implement 'simple'deletion POC
HierarchicalRequirement.Notes: Referential Integrity for deletes was understood to be handled by the DAL.  Unfortunately, Sean Melody, in a note on the confluence page associated with this story, reports that that functionality is not scheduled to be added until the next sprint.  We will add code to handle the exception that should get thrown when RI is broken and @WIP the acceptance test for now.  We will also add tech debt to make sure these items are revisited (DE#### - to be added) and assign it originally to the team that knows the most about the DAL (parallax).  In NeutralRecordEntityDeleteHandler, the 'delete' method currently throw an EntityValidationException; we'll probably have to change that, depending on how the RI check is implemented in the DAL.

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Migrate Pit Nodes to Service multiple Maestro Nodes simultaneously
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
The primary focus of this story is to ensure that pit nodes can service multiple maestros, indicating that if several ingestion batch jobs are simultaneously started (via multiple maestros), that pit nodes will perform work in the order of which maestro nodes put work notes onto the work item queue, and use batchJobId (on the work note) to perform any transformation or persistence (into 'is' or 'sli' data stores). 

Acceptance criteria need to be agreed upon by Danil Kornishev, Igor Faybyshev, Danilo Duran, and Stan Halka, as this story is specific to pit nodes. Galactus is currently playing the sister story, which is to migrate to multiple maestros. Lucky Strike also has a story to create a multi-tenancy acceptance test, which might (or might not) be utilized in accepting this story.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Migrate Pit Nodes to Service multiple Maestro Nodes simultaneously

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Epic: Ingestion Progress

HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Epic: Ingestion Progress
HierarchicalRequirement.ReleaseNoteDescription: During bulk data ingestion, there is no progress indication for an ingestion job until the job is complete. The uploaded .zip file is immediately removed from the user's landing zone and the job log file(s) do not appear in its place until the job is complete.

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Measure ingestion performance
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Acceptance criteria: (from Richard)

Overall, as SLI integration administrator/support, I need to have the capability to measure the integration performance in an ongoing basis. In each release of the software platform, I would like to keep track of a basic integration performance matrix. The goal is to use the matrix to measure the performance profile of the integration platform. Specifically, the following is the important numbers we want to track and improve upon:

1. End-to-end time for any particular job (for example, upload job, validation job, match job, publish job, etc.) for a distribution of job size (small job size (100 records), medium job size (20,000 records), large job size (1.5 million records)

2. End-to-end time for a particular realm provisioning. This is what the user would experience as the initial integration performance and this also will have matrix for (small (100 students realm), medium (20,000 students realm), large (1.5 million students realm))

3. End-to-end time for an incremental integration session (after the initial provisioning. This is what the user would experience as the operational integration performance and this also will have matrix for  (small (100 students realm), medium (20,000 students realm), large (1.5 million students realm)) with "net change rate" at average of 10%.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Measure ingestion performance

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Investigate ingestion performance during prep for R1.0
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Current hypothesis is that the performance testing results are misleading due to differences in infrastructure and/or datastore setups during subsequent performance runs.

work with Tony Requist to make sure the appropriate data sets are being used.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Second Phase (Compare before and after reference resolution code releases with updated performance test suite(s)):

Suite 1 (Performance Tests on Team SIP with before code release):
  1. set up Team SIP with necessary software installed, including Mongo sharding and pre-splitting configured as in production.
  2. deploy the before code
  3. deploy/copy the necessary data set(s)
  4. run reset script to ensure consistent environment prior to each performance run
  5. setup the available Mongo cluster/sharding statistics tooling required to measure scatter/gather info
  6. run the performance tests
  7. document the results including the total timing, application Mongo operations, and Mongo cluster/sharding statistics
  8. reset for the next test to ensure consistent environment
  9. then run it several more times
  10. review results, confirm limited variance, and document confident baseline for before code.
Suite 2 (Performance Tests on Team SIP with periodic DID code releases):
  1. adjust Team SIP environment and configure Mongo sharding and pre-splitting to use new DIDs.
  2. periodically deploy the current DID team branch code to Team SIP environment
  3. run reset script to ensure consistent environment prior to each performance run
  4. run the performance tests
  5. document the results including the total timing, application Mongo operations, and Mongo cluster/sharding statistics
  6. reset for the next test to ensure consistent environment
  7. then run it several more times
  8. analyze results, and confirm potential performance gains as total DID entities grow as a percentage of total SLI entities.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Investigate ingestion performance during prep for R1.0

HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Capacity boundary (Stretch goals)
Measure the environment that is running the integration jobs. This matrix is about the stretching the boundary of the running environment and find the optimal system configuration of running the integration jobs. The number we want to measure are:

CPU consumption when jobs are running 
Memory when jobs are running 
I/O write when jobs are running (only applicable to certain I/O intensive jobs)

The number of simultaneous jobs running when CPU reach 80% above and/or Memory reach 80% above
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Ingestion Performance (post PI4)

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Spike: How to calculate delta's
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Define how to calculate delta's on a second load of a dataset that we have seen before.
 
Ingestion of Deltas on Day N will be the center piece of ingestion moving forward.  Focus on full regular ingestions is not a supportable strategy.
 
Current proposal is off-line tool to calculate deltas between submissions.
 
Workflow of current proposal:
 
Client runs tool with latest data from source system and data from last submission.  The off-line tool produces one or more interchanges that contains a diff between the last submission and the proposed submission for each interchange that has been supplied.  Each interchange is considered the full snapshot for that entity type for that ingestion user.  Deletions MUST be calculated and how they are expressed in interchange MUST be carefully considered, in light of deletion POC already executed. 
 
 
Acceptance Criteria:
The effect of doing this on a live system with potential entity level inserts, updates and deletes coming in concurrently through the API MUST be considered and described.  It is currently not considered a deal breaker to have ingestion of deltas and apps overwriting each other's data.
 
The effect of calculating deltas between data sets with the current data model and the proposed r1 data model MUST be considered.
 
MUST be assumed that interchanges will contain only one type of Entity (or Super Entity in case of proposed data model)
 
Results MUST be clearly documented on Confluence.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Spike: How to calculate delta's

  • No IDs are random, all are deterministically generated on an entity by entity basis.

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Reference Resolution - Epic
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
REFERENCE RESOLUTION FRAMEWORK (NOT Deterministic IDs)
-SPIKE : What's the architectural plan for completing the reference resolution framework?
-Implement framework with tracer bullet (POC, measure perf)
-Implement it for all objects that are referenced (22 id types, and id types that are referenced that are currently undefined).
-Testing, etc (not separate in actual implementation)
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Reference Resolution - Epic

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Reference Resolution - SPIKE - What's the architectural plan for completing the reference resolution framework?
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
• current JSON configuration vs. schema driven configuration (annotations) -->yes to annotations
  • plan for how we integrate this with Lucky Strikes context work
  • ensure documentation is up to date
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
EMAIL FROM JON TULLY(10/2/2012):

I just spoke to Aaron about these issues. Here's a summary of our discussion:

  1. Pantheon will move towards Ed-Fi schema annotations to replace the JSON reference configuration.
    • Pantheon will come up with a design for the annotations early in 6.3.
    • All other (non-reference-resolution) entity configuration will remain in the EntityConfig JSON files for now.
  2.  All 'context stamping' code should be separated from reference resolution (refactored out of IdNormalizer).
    • Pantheon will be dependent on this to switch on deterministic id ref resolution.
    • Need to determine who will do this work (Lucky Strike or Pantheon?).

I am still concerned about whether the Ed-Fi annotations will end up being too messy.  Remember that these must configure the mappings between Ed-Fi fields and SLI key fields and also describe how deterministic id calculations for each reference type should be nested (a SectionReferenceType is resolved by calculating an edOrg DID and then using that in the calculation of a section DID), so they are a lot more complicated than the equivalent annotations on the SLI side.  That being said, I think we can proceed under the assumption that it will work.

Let us know ASAP if there are any other concerns.  If not, I think we have enough direction to be able to plan tomorrow.

Thanks,

Jon
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Reference Resolution - SPIKE - What's the architectural plan for completing the reference resolution framework?

Task.refObjectName: Create sample annotation (there are two sets: annotations on the IdentityType, and annotations on the entity that has the reference) for a non-trivial entity
Create documentation, incorporate feedback from Sean
Coordinate Pantheon and Wolverine Approaches for EDFI XML Reference Structures

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Reference Resolution - Implement it for all objects that are referenced (21 id types, and 11 id types that are referenced that are currently undefined).
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
Our goal is to provide natural key resolution paths for all references.

Implement it for all objects that are referenced (21 ReferenceType/IdentityTypes, 2 ReferenceType/IdentityTypes that are referenced that are currently undefined, and 11 ReferenceType/IdentityTypes needed in addition):
  • make brand new reference types and identity types for the ones with references that are undefined.
  • make pre-existing id types match the natural keys that we defined last sprint
    • different work for different entitites
  • for all the places we use pur reference types wen need to convert to use the specific reference types 
    • pure reference can only be resolved through ID/IDRef
    • (combo referency types?)specific reference types can be resolved through ID/IDRef or natural keys
  • Categories of reference types for any give object:
    • no changes necessary (reference is already in desired shape)
    • optional elements may need to be changed to be "required"
    • attributes may need to be removed because it's not part of natural key
    • may need to add new attributes
    • may need to make a required element optional
    • may need to make "choices" (xml designator) in the reference type
  • Datasets will need to be changed in order to ensure that tests pass
— Anything that uses ID/IDRef can and will still use ID/IDRef upon completion of this story.

21 EdFi defined ReferenceType/IdentityTypes we handle
2 EdFi defined ReferenceType/IdentityTypes we don't handle

11 ReferenceType/IdentityTypes needed in addition:
- AcademicWeek
- Diploma
- Grade
- GradebookEntry
- GraduationPlan
- MeetingTime
- ReportCard
- StudentAcademicRecord
- StudentAssessment
- StudentCompetency
- StudentObjectiveAssessment

AcademicWeek
- CalendarDateReference *

Assessment
- AssessmentItemReference *
- ObjectiveAssessmentReference *

BellSchedule
- MeetingTimeReference

CourseTranscript
- StudentAcademicRecordReference *

GradingPeriod
- CalendarDateReference *

ObjectiveAssessment
- AssessmentItemReference *
- ObjectiveAssessmentReference *

ReportCard
- GradeReference
- StudentCompetencyReference

School
- ClassPeriodReference *
- LocationReference *

Session
- CalendarDateReference *
- AcademicWeekReference

StudentAcademicRecord
- ReportCardReference
- DiplomaReference

StudentAssessmentItem
- StudentAssessmentReference
- StudentObjectiveAssessmentReference

StudentGradebookEntry
- GradebookEntryReference

StudentObjectiveAssessment
- StudentAssessmentReference

StudentDisciplineIncidentAssociation
- DisciplineIncidentReference *

StudentSchoolAssociation
- GraduationPlanReference

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Reference Resolution - Implement for existing IdentityTypes
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
REQUIREMENTS:
  1. Ingestion user must be able to use a natural key to reference each entity reference type listed.
  2. For each reference currently used as a pure reference, the ingestion user must be able to resolve one of these through natural keys as well.
ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
  • Uses deterministic ID reference resolution and not old JSON.
  • make pre-existing id types match the natural keys that we defined for DIDS
    • different work for different entitites
  • for all the places we use pure reference types wen need to convert to use the specific reference types 
    • since pure reference can only be resolved through ID/IDRef
    • (combo reference types?)specific reference types can be resolved through ID/IDRef or natural keys
  • Possilbe changes to existing reference types may be:
    • no changes necessary (reference is already in desired shape)
    • optional elements may need to be changed to be "required"
    • attributes may need to be removed because it's not part of natural key
    • may need to add new attributes
    • may need to make a required element optional
    • may need to make "choices" (xml designator) in the reference type
  • Datasets will need to be changed in order to ensure that tests pass
— Anything that uses ID/IDRef can and will still use ID/IDRef upon completion of this story.

TASKS
  • make the changes to the IdentityType in the EdFi extension XSD
  • Annotate IdentityType
  • normalize smooks for all entities containing references to this object
  • find any pure reference types for this entity, change them over to the specific ReferenceType in the EDFi extension XSD.
  • if necessary, fix the data generator to generate proper reference shapes
  • if necessary, regenerate generated data sets that have now-improper reference shapes
    • 100K and up?
  • fix acceptance tests and data sets
    • SDS, Medium Data Sets, other XML that's used in acceptance tests
  • code review
  • These are the places where EdFi uses pure references:

    • AcademicWeek has a pure reference to 
    • - CalendarDateReference (specific reference type exists but is unused)
    • Assessment
    • - AssessmentItemReference *
    • - ObjectiveAssessmentReference *
    • CourseTranscript
    • - StudentAcademicRecordReference *
    • GradingPeriod
    • - CalendarDateReference *
    • ObjectiveAssessment
    • - AssessmentItemReference *
    • - ObjectiveAssessmentReference *
    • School
    • - ClassPeriodReference *
    • - LocationReference *
    • Session
    • - CalendarDateReference *
    • - AcademicWeekReference
    • StudentDisciplineIncidentAssociation
    • - DisciplineIncidentReference *

  • The below should have been completed in 6.3, but if it isn't do it as part of this story:
    • StudentSchoolAssociation
    • - GraduationPlanReference
    • StudentAcademicRecord
    • - ReportCardReference
    • - DiplomaReference
    • StudentAssessmentItem
    • - StudentAssessmentReference
    • - StudentObjectiveAssessmentReference
    • StudentGradebookEntry
    • - GradebookEntryReference
    • StudentObjectiveAssessment
    • - StudentAssessmentReference
    • ReportCard
    • - GradeReference
    • - StudentCompetencyReference

Objects with EdFi defined IdentityTypes (ignoring 2 we do not map):
  • Assessment -2
  • AssessmentFamily -2
  • AssessmentItem -2
  • CalendarDate -2
  • Cohort -2
  • Course -2
  • CourseOffering -2
  • DisciplineIncident -2
  • EducationOrganization -2
  • GradingPeriod -2
  • LearningObjective -2
  • LearningStandard -2
  • ObjectiveAssessment -2
  • Parent -2
  • Program -2
  • Session -2
  • Staff -2
  • Student -2

ACCEPTANCE TESTS:
The pre-existing SDS test should do the following:
  • Data set contains at least one entity B with an IdentityType reference to the entity A you are working on.
  • Test confirms that the entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.
  • For the pure ReferenceType instances, data set contains at least one instance of each entity B pointing to entity A via IDREF.
  • Test confirms that at least one of each entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.

If these tests are missing, you should add them before starting work.

To test this story (per entity):
  • The SDS should pass - this confirms that you have not broken the previously working IdentityType reference resolution.
  • For each entity B that used to use a pure ReferenceType to reference your entity A, change the SDS so that on one instance, you remove the IDREF field and add the ReferenceType/IdentityType/natural keys fields.  The SDS should pass - this confirms that you have correctly implemented IdentityType resolution where previously only IDREF worked.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Reference Resolution - Implement for existing IdentityTypes

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Reference Resolution - Implement for existing IdentityTypes - GradingPeriod
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
DETAIL

An Ingestion user must be able to use a natural key to reference each entity reference type listed, specifically there must be a natural key to reference the LearningObjective reference type. For each reference currently used as a pure reference, the ingestion user must be able to resolve one of these through natural keys as well.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
  • Uses deterministic ID reference resolution and not old JSON.
  • Make LearningObjective Reference match the natural keys that we defined for LearningObjective.
  • For all the places we use pure reference types wen need to convert to use the specific reference types 
    • since pure reference can only be resolved through ID/IDRef
    • (combo reference types?)specific reference types can be resolved through ID/IDRef or natural keys
  • Possilbe changes to existing reference types may be:
    • no changes necessary (reference is already in desired shape)
    • optional elements may need to be changed to be "required"
    • attributes may need to be removed because it's not part of natural key
    • may need to add new attributes
    • may need to make a required element optional
    • may need to make "choices" (xml designator) in the reference type
  • Datasets will need to be changed in order to ensure that tests pass
— If necessary we can get rid of ID/IDRef.

TASKS
DEFINE STORY SPECIFIC TASKS HERE 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
FOR MORE INFORMATION SEE PARENT EPIC
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

    ACCEPTANCE TESTS:
    The pre-existing SDS test should do the following:
    • Data set contains at least one entity B with an IdentityType reference to the entity A you are working on.
    • Test confirms that the entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.
    • For the pure ReferenceType instances, data set contains at least one instance of each entity B pointing to entity A via IDREF.
    • Test confirms that at least one of each entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.

    If these tests are missing, you should add them before starting work.

    To test this story (per entity):
    • The SDS should pass - this confirms that you have not broken the previously working IdentityType reference resolution.
    • For each entity B that used to use a pure ReferenceType to reference your entity A, change the SDS so that on one instance, you remove the IDREF field and add the ReferenceType/IdentityType/natural keys fields.  The SDS should pass - this confirms that you have correctly implemented IdentityType resolution where previously only IDREF worked.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Reference Resolution - Implement for existing IdentityTypes - GradingPeriod

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Reference Resolution - Implement for existing IdentityTypes - Cohort
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
REQUIREMENTS:
  1. Ingestion user must be able to use a natural key to reference each entity reference type listed.
  2. For each reference currently used as a pure reference, the ingestion user must be able to resolve one of these through natural keys as well.
ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
  • Uses deterministic ID reference resolution and not old JSON.
  • make pre-existing id types match the natural keys that we defined for DIDS
    • different work for different entitites
  • for all the places we use pure reference types wen need to convert to use the specific reference types 
    • since pure reference can only be resolved through ID/IDRef
    • (combo reference types?)specific reference types can be resolved through ID/IDRef or natural keys
  • Possilbe changes to existing reference types may be:
    • no changes necessary (reference is already in desired shape)
    • optional elements may need to be changed to be "required"
    • attributes may need to be removed because it's not part of natural key
    • may need to add new attributes
    • may need to make a required element optional
    • may need to make "choices" (xml designator) in the reference type
  • Datasets will need to be changed in order to ensure that tests pass
— Anything that uses ID/IDRef can and will still use ID/IDRef upon completion of this story.

TASKS
  • make the changes to the IdentityType in the EdFi extension XSD
  • Annotate IdentityType
  • normalize smooks for all entities containing references to this object
  • find any pure reference types for this entity, change them over to the specific ReferenceType in the EDFi extension XSD.
  • if necessary, fix the data generator to generate proper reference shapes
  • if necessary, regenerate generated data sets that have now-improper reference shapes
    • 100K and up?
  • fix acceptance tests and data sets
    • SDS, Medium Data Sets, other XML that's used in acceptance tests
  • code review
  • These are the places where EdFi uses pure references:

    • AcademicWeek has a pure reference to 
    • - CalendarDateReference (specific reference type exists but is unused)
    • Assessment
    • - AssessmentItemReference *
    • - ObjectiveAssessmentReference *
    • CourseTranscript
    • - StudentAcademicRecordReference *
    • GradingPeriod
    • - CalendarDateReference *
    • ObjectiveAssessment
    • - AssessmentItemReference *
    • - ObjectiveAssessmentReference *
    • School
    • - ClassPeriodReference *
    • - LocationReference *
    • Session
    • - CalendarDateReference *
    • - AcademicWeekReference
    • StudentDisciplineIncidentAssociation
    • - DisciplineIncidentReference *

  • The below should have been completed in 6.3, but if it isn't do it as part of this story:
    • StudentSchoolAssociation
    • - GraduationPlanReference
    • StudentAcademicRecord
    • - ReportCardReference
    • - DiplomaReference
    • StudentAssessmentItem
    • - StudentAssessmentReference
    • - StudentObjectiveAssessmentReference
    • StudentGradebookEntry
    • - GradebookEntryReference
    • StudentObjectiveAssessment
    • - StudentAssessmentReference
    • ReportCard
    • - GradeReference
    • - StudentCompetencyReference

Objects with EdFi defined IdentityTypes (ignoring 2 we do not map):
  • Assessment -2
  • AssessmentFamily -2
  • AssessmentItem -2
  • CalendarDate -2
  • Cohort -2
  • Course -2
  • CourseOffering -2
  • DisciplineIncident -2

  • LearningObjective -2
  • LearningStandard -2
  • ObjectiveAssessment -2
  • Parent -2
  • Program -2
  • Session -2
  • Staff -2
  • Student -2

ACCEPTANCE TESTS:
The pre-existing SDS test should do the following:
  • Data set contains at least one entity B with an IdentityType reference to the entity A you are working on.
  • Test confirms that the entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.
  • For the pure ReferenceType instances, data set contains at least one instance of each entity B pointing to entity A via IDREF.
  • Test confirms that at least one of each entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.

If these tests are missing, you should add them before starting work.

To test this story (per entity):
  • The SDS should pass - this confirms that you have not broken the previously working IdentityType reference resolution.
  • For each entity B that used to use a pure ReferenceType to reference your entity A, change the SDS so that on one instance, you remove the IDREF field and add the ReferenceType/IdentityType/natural keys fields.  The SDS should pass - this confirms that you have correctly implemented IdentityType resolution where previously only IDREF worked.

REQUIREMENTS:
  1. Ingestion user must be able to use a natural key to reference each entity reference type listed.

    • optional elements may need to be changed to be "required"
    • attributes may need to be removed because it's not part of natural key

  • Datasets will need to be changed in order to ensure that tests pass
— If necessary we can get rid of ID/IDRef.

  • make the changes to the IdentityType in the EdFi extension XSD

  • if necessary, regenerate generated data sets that have now-improper reference shapes
    • 100K and up?
  • fix acceptance tests and data sets
    • SDS, Medium Data Sets, other XML that's used in acceptance tests
  • code review

    • - ObjectiveAssessmentReference *

    • GradingPeriod

    • - AcademicWeekReference
    • StudentDisciplineIncidentAssociation

    • StudentSchoolAssociation

    • StudentAcademicRecord

    • StudentObjectiveAssessment

  • Student -2

  • For the pure ReferenceType instances, data set contains at least one instance of each entity B pointing to entity A via IDREF.
  • Test confirms that at least one of each entity B ingests successfully and resolves the reference to entity A.

If these tests are missing, you should add them before starting work.

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Updating for Natural Key Fields
Remove ID/ID ref in the XSDs (Deprecate ID/ID Ref)
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
This falls under tying a "bow" on the deterministic ID work.

We'll remove ID/ID ref in the XSD, publishing a new one and communicating it externally.

When we finish natural keys and reference type work then id/idref will be an independent. What are the advantages to removing ID/ID Refs? What are the consequences?

Dependency:
— customer has signed off that this is okay to do and is aware of any consequences
— US3951 - reference resolution, need to have "both sides" of DIDs complete before we can turn off id/idref for entitities that are using it currently. 
— There are currently idrefs that are being used for entities that do not have identity types, we'll need to add identity types.

In general, "phasing out or removal" stories can involve four phases:

1)  Generate lightweight framework to allow both "original" and incremental "new" SW module implementations to coexist until complete "phase out" of original module.

2)  Complete new implementation of phased out original SW module such that all original features have been accounted for.

3)  Any code referencing "original" SW module is refactored to reference "new" implementation.

4)  Remove any framework or scaffolding code which supported incremental refactoring.

Furthermore, the tasks here can parallel or reflect the associated EDFI entities or even interchanges to allow task distribution among teams or team members.

AC—
— There are no id/idref references in the xsds
— All of the sli entities can be ingested without using the idref mechanism
— Needs to be packaged for documentation
— Here's the list of all the id/idrefs:
— identity types for entitites without them have been added and the natural keys are created.

TASKS:  (Jon)

Remove all idref references from all acceptance test data sets and replace with natural key refs
    -how many entities does this apply to? (need a script for each one)

Change the data generator to generate only natural key references
       -how many entities does this apply to?
       For Medium data set, the following entities are using IdRef (based on a grep):
<StudentAssessmentReference ref=
<CalendarDateReference ref=
<DisciplineIncidentReference ref=
<GradingPeriodReference ref=
<LocalEducationAgencyReference ref=
<ParentReference ref=
<ProgramReference ref=
<StateEducationAgencyReference ref=
<StudentAcademicRecordReference ref=
<StudentReference ref=


Change the base refererenceType in SLI-Ed-Fi-Core.xsd to require an identity type and not use @ref

Strip out all idref code from ingestion - there is a lot of this

(Steve)
There are about 20 places where setRef() is called in the data generator. Each one will need to be replaced with the appropriate reference structure.

TASKS
  • 4 - StudentAssessmentReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - CalendarDateReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - DisciplineIncidentReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - GradingPeriodReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - LocalEducationAgencyReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - ParentReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - ProgramReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - StateEducationAgencyReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - StudentAcademicRecordReference - Update Small and Medium data sets to remove id-ref
  • 4 - add tasks for all other IDREF entities in small and medium data sets
  • 4 - Update XSDs to force id-refs to result in warnings (make every IdentityType required); change ReferenceType to not have ID or REF; use SLC-ReferenceType instead of ReferenceType everywhere we’re doing reference resolution
  • 1 - Remove IDRef tests (if you leave them in code, add comments as to why they’ve been removed)
  • 6 - add one acceptance test check per IDREF to check for warnings if IDRefs are present
  • 0 - do not remove ID from base EdFi entities
  • 0 - leave IDRefs in data sets anywhere they don’t break tests
  • 0 - leave in IDRef code

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Allow concurrent ingestion jobs for a tenant
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an Ingestion user I would like to be able to execute multiple ingestion jobs within the same tenant.
Remove Tenant Level Lock - Ask Danny....

AC:
Time-boxed 3 points.
Tenant users can submit multiple ingestion jobs to be processed at the same time
User and dev documentation is updated
Standard SLA's for a file pick up
Create Rally Defects for identified problem scenarios/issues after multiple ingestion jobs per tenant feature enabled.
 
Test Cases:
 

ingest one data set

two data sets - same landing zones, different landing zones

5 different data sets that don't overlap

5 different data sets, 4 are ok and one will generate significant errors.

drop three big jobs, drop three small jobs and see what happens.....

Try to ingest 10 jobs into the same tenant.......
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Allow concurrent ingestion jobs for a tenant
HierarchicalRequirement.Notes:
Galactus Meeting (08/23/2012) - Clarify "at the same time" requirements.
Is it a requirement to support concurrent jobs for the same LZ? Yes. (OV 08/24/2012)

Team Meeting 08/29/2012: Define "Standard SLA's for a file pick up". for Olga.
We can document issues that we found during the work on the story. Add them as a tech debt.
We assume we do not need to fix any data issues (data dependencies) identified during the execution of the story. If don't do deterministic ids we may potentially insert same record twice (race conditions?). Should we implement upserts? Remove lock, make sure the route is configured to have a dedicated thread for it. Remove the api change that Nick was working on.
 
Potentially affects ingestion behavior, depending on result of evalution and choice of remediations.

SY (10/15/2012): Blocked on (DE1854)

11/6/2012: DE2065, defect for storm for runbook update

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Replacing Camel polling with Active MQ
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an SLI application, I want a safe way of guranteeing that only one maestro processes a file so that ingestion users will be able to present files without the variety of errors that may occur from race conditions between the Gluster file system and the SLI application.
 
 
 
See background discussion:
https://thesli.onconfluence.com/display/sli/Replacing+Camel+Polling+with+ProFTP+and+Activemq
https://thesli.onconfluence.com/display/sli/Gluster+Issue+DE1618
 
 
Goals of POC: 
  1. Make sure this is workable in ProFTP
  2. Make sure there are no security issues
  3. Determine the strategy for local machines and acceptance tests
    It is not trivial given the number of tests to change, but it it not huge
  4. Make sure that Operator environment will allow for communication between proFTP and ActiveMQ
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Replacing Camel polling with Active MQ
HierarchicalRequirement.Notes: on how one might inject a message upon completion of an sftp PUT, see http://www.proftpd.org/docs/contrib/mod_exec.html and ExecOnCommand.

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: complete US4245: Replacing Camel polling with Active MQ

https://thesli.onconfluence.com/display/sli/Replacing+Camel+Polling+with+ProFTP+and+Activemq

  4. Make sure that Operator environment will allow for communication between proFTP and ActiveMQ

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Disable Reference Validation
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
DETAIL
Part of Data modification required for performance and scalability. Current Issues are that reference validation requires many SLI database reads. Mongo does not perform well with interspersed reads and writes.

What is the justification for removing reference validation? We're not the system of record. We will trust that the data we get from schools is valid.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
No SLI database reads
  • Reference validation is removed. This leaves a pure write load to the SLI database.

TASKS - Vic
Remove the reference check in ReferenceSchema.java
Fix applicable unit and acceptance tests
Ensure resolved reference is a non empty string
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Disable Reference Validation

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Record Level Deltas Complex Entities - Student Transcript Association Combiner (Stretch)
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an SLI application, I want complex entities to be supported during Record Level Delta Processing so that Complex entities can be ingested quickly on Day N.
 
 
Success or failure of ingestion of the entities connected the the transformer in the title needs to add record hashes or not.  During Transformation, maintain list of record hashes that went into a transformed entity. 
 
 
AC:
Unit Testing MUST cover Mongo Error conditions with simulation wherever possible.
 
Scenario: Ingest Complex entity components
Given I am an ingestion user
And, I have existing data in the data store
And I have XML that I have an interchange file with two entities that fit into the above complex entity
And, I sftp this interchange file with a control file to the landing zone
And, I get no error file during ingestion
When I query the record hash collection with the _id of each entity, an entry will be found
 
Scenario: Ingest Complex entity components second time
Given I am an ingestion user
And, I have existing data in the data store
And I have XML that I have an interchange file with two entities that fit into the above complex entity
And, I have already ingested this XML once
And, I sftp this interchange file with a control file to the landing zone
And, I get no error file during ingestion
When I query the record hash collection with the _id of each entity, an entry will be found with a timestamp that is earlier than the current time.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Record Level Deltas Complex Entities - Student Transcript Association Combiner (Stretch)

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Provide a mechanism to skip delta processing
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an Ingestion User I would like to be able to force complete Ingestion without delta processing in case if my data was corrupted by non Ingestion process.


Specific Use Case:
I ingested my data
Some API process changed too many things for me to figure out what is wrong with my current data
I just want to reset my database to the previous known situation.

(This can be day 1 specific or day n specific, details need to be figured out ).
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Provide a mechanism to skip delta processing

HierarchicalRequirement.refObjectName: Add Reversion Support for Record Level Deltas
HierarchicalRequirement.Description:
As an ingestion user, I want to be able to revert changes made to entities and have the derived deltas respect that change so that the derived deltas process will be transparent to me.
 
 
The case where an ingestion user ingestions data with a specific student name, Sends a data set the next data with a change to that name, and the next day reverts that change back to the original is currently not handled (the last change will be ignored.
 
Acceptance Criteria:
 
Gherkin:
 
Scenario: Duplicate Creation Data Set
Given a data set has been ingested 
When the same data set is presented for ingestion
Then the entities are not updated
And no new entities are created
And the hash records are not updated
And no new hash records are created

Scenario:  Updated Data, Duplicate Update and Reversion
Given a data set has been ingested
When updates for that data set are presented for ingestion
Then the entitiess are updated
And no new entities are created
And the hash record are updated with an updated hash of the entity
And no new hash records are created
When the same updates are presented for ingestion
Then the entities are not updated
And no new entities are created
And the hash records are not updated
And no new hash records are created
When the original dataset is presented for ingestion
Then the entities are updated to the original values
And no new entities are created
And the hash records are updated to the original values
And no new hash records are created

Additional AT may be required for when the update to the hash record fails for some reason.

Testing Notes:

1. The original dataset to include examples of each type of entity
2. The update data set to include an update for each entity type
3. Ideally - The update data set to include updates of each entity field where it is valid to do so.  These are to be combined where possible.
HierarchicalRequirement.Name: Add Reversion Support for Record Level Deltas
HierarchicalRequirement.Notes:
Defect specific properties:
Defect State: Open
Priority: Next Interim Release (P3)
Severity: Usable but incorrect behavior (Sev3)
